prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HDO transitions at 225 and 241 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the HDO 3_{1,2}-2_{2,1} and 2_{1,1}-2_{1,2} at 225.8967 and 241.5616 GHz with a signal-to-noise ratio of 40 and a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec to clearly map this line and detect line wings. The pointing is done at a position between the source A and the source B, such as the two sources are observed simultaneously.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3". The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s. The peak intensities of the two HDO lines (see Table 2) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013). We checked that they are consistent with the RATRAN modeling of HDO done by Coutens et al. (2012). The lines will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 40 to be able to detect the line wings and study both the kinematics and the spatial distribution with these two lines. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, Jørgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency. The two sources fits within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. A single pointing is then sufficient to observe the two sources A and B. Another HDO line at 241.973 GHz will be targetted in the same setup for a tentative detection. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations. Additional bonus lines can be observed simultaneously for a reasonable data rate (6 Mb/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Ground-state para-D2O transition at 316 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the para-D2O ground-state 1_{1,0}-1_{0,1} line and the HDO 5_{4,2}-6_{3,3} excited line at 316.7998 and 317.1513 GHz respectively, with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 5 is required for the observation of the D2O line. The pointing is done at a position between the source A and the source B, such as the two sources are observed simultaneously.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3". The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s. The peak intensities of the para-D2O and HDO lines (see Table 2) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013) for HDO and Coutens et al. (2013) for D2O. We checked that they are consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2012, 2013). The fundamental para-D2O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of at least 5 for a detection and a determination of the D2O/H2O ratio at the position of the peak emission. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, Jørgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency. The two sources fits within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. A single pointing is then sufficient to observe the two sources A and B. Another HDO line at 305.038 GHz will be targetted in the same setup for a tentative detection. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations. Additional bonus lines can be observed simultaneously for a reasonable data rate (6 Mb/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2-18O transition at 322 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the para-H2-18O 5_{1,5}-4_{2,2} line at 322.4652 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 10 is required for the observation of this line. Two additional HDO lines at 310.53 and 313.75 GHz (expected more intense than the H2-18O line) can be observed simultaneously. The pointing is done at a position between the source A and the source B, such as the two sources are observed simultaneously.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3". The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s. The peak intensities of the para-H2-18O and HDO lines (see Table 2) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013). We checked that the HDO intensities are consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2012). The para-H2-18O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 to be mapped. The HDO lines will be then observed with more than 10 sigma, as they are expected to be brighter than the H2-18O line. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, Jørgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency. The two sources fits within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. A single pointing is then sufficient to observe the two sources A and B. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations. Additional bonus lines can be observed simultaneously for a reasonable data rate (6 Mb/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2-18O transition at 391 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the ortho-H2-18O 4_{1,4}-3_{2,1} transition at 390.6078 GHz and the ortho-D2O 2_{1,1}-2_{0,2} transition at 403.5618 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 10 is required for the observation of the D2O line. The ortho-H2-18O should be detected with an SNR of more than 20. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3". The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s. The peak intensities of the ortho-H2-18O and ortho-D2O lines (see Table 2) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013) for H2-18O and Coutens et al. (2013) for D2O. We checked that the D2O line estimate is consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2013). The D2O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 to be mapped. The H2-18O line will be then observed with more than 20 sigma. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, Jørgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency. The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations. Additional bonus lines can be observed simultaneously for a reasonable data rate (6 Mb/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Ground-state HDO transition at 464 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the HDO ground-state 1_{0,1}-0_{0,0} transition at 464.9245 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 40 is required to clearly map this line and detect line wings. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3". The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s. The peak intensity of the fundamental HDO line (see Table 2) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013) for HDO. We checked that the HDO line estimate is consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2012). The HDO line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 40 to be able to detect the line wings and study both the kinematics and the spatial distribution. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, Jørgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency. The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B. Two HD-18O line at 462.23 and 453.31 GHz will be targetted in the same setup for a tentative detection. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations. Additional bonus lines can be observed simultaneously for a reasonable data rate (6 Mb/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2-18O transition at 489 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the ortho-H2-18O 4_{2,3}-3_{3,0} transition at 489.0543 GHz and the HDO 2_{0,2}-1_{1,1} transition at 490.5966 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 10 is required for the observation of the H2-18O line. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3". The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s. The peak intensities of the ortho-H2-18O and HDO lines (see Table 2) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013). We checked that the HDO line estimate is consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2012). The H2-18O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 to be mapped. The HDO line will then also be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 10 as its line intensity is quite similar to the H2-18O line. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, Jørgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency. The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B. An HD-18O line at 492.81 GHz will be targetted in the same setup for a tentative detection. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations. Additional bonus lines can be observed simultaneously for a reasonable data rate (6 Mb/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Ground-state ortho-D2O transition at 607 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the ortho-D2O ground-state 1_{1,1}-0_{0,0} transition at 607.3496 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 5 is required to detect the D2O line. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3". The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s. The peak intensity of the fundamental ortho-D2O line (see Table 2) is estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Coutens et al. (2013). We checked that the D2O line estimate is also consistent with the RATRAN modeling. The fundamental para-D2O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of at least 5 for a detection and a determination of the D2O/H2O ratio at the position of the peak emission. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, Jørgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency. The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations. Additional bonus lines can be observed simultaneously for a reasonable data rate (6 Mb/s).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The evolution of water from its formation in the molecular cloud until its incorporation in the protoplanetary disk and then comets and asteroids is still unclear. Measuring the water D/H ratio is particularly helpful to answer this question. We propose to carry out multi-line observations of the water isotopologues (HDO, H2-18O and D2O) at high spatial resolution (0.3arcsec, 35 AU diameter) towards the inner regions of the well-known Class 0 protobinary IRAS16293-2422, which is now possible thanks to the enhanced capabilities of ALMA cycle 2. Through the study of the kinematics and the determination of the HDO/H2O and D2O/H2O ratios with radius from the protostars, we can determine if the water present at the Class 0 stage was preserved or reprocessed until its incorporation in disks and primitive icy bodies. The data will also allow us to determine the mechanisms that control the water vapor abundance in the warm inner regions of Class 0 protostars.
